prompt: Facts: Marriage between Rashmi Gupta (Complainant/Respondent 2) and Deepak Gupta solemnized on 04.02.2003 in Delhi.; After marriage, the couple resided in Delhi.; Preeti Gupta (Appellant 1, sister-in-law/nanad of Complainant) resided in Navasari, Gujarat.; Pradeep Gupta (Appellant 2, brother-in-law/devar of Complainant) resided in Howrah, West Bengal.; Appellants never lived with the Complainant and her husband in Delhi.; Complainant left her matrimonial home in Delhi on 17.01.2005.; Complainant filed Complaint Case No. 369 of 2005 before the Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM), Ranchi, Jharkhand on 11.04.2005.; Complaint alleged torture, harassment, and dowry demands against husband (Deepak Gupta), father-in-law (Ghanshyam Gupta), mother-in-law (Sarla Gupta), sister-in-law (Appellant 1), and brother-in-law (Appellant 2).; Allegations against Appellants 1 and 2 were described by the Supreme Court as 'general and omnibus', lacking specific details of time, place, or nature of acts.; CJM, Ranchi took cognizance under Sections 498A, 406 IPC and Sections 3/4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act against all accused, including the appellants, on 13.04.2005.; Appellants filed Cr. M.P. No. 1559 of 2005 under Section 482 CrPC before the Jharkhand High Court seeking quashing of proceedings against them.; Jharkhand High Court dismissed the quashing petition on 18.06.2007.; Appellants appealed the High Court's dismissal order to the Supreme Court of India.; Supreme Court observed a growing trend of implicating all relatives in matrimonial disputes under Section 498A IPC, often with vague allegations.; Supreme Court noted the appellants' separate residences and lack of specific accusations against them in the complaint. | IPC: Section 498A, Section 406
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The appellants, along with other family members, subjected the complainant to cruelty and harassment for dowry, constituting an offense under Section 498A IPC.", "precedents": ["Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra, (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Definition and scope of 'cruelty')", "Kaliyaperumal v. State of Tamil Nadu, (2004) 9 SCC 157 (Essential ingredients of Section 498A)", "State of Karnataka v. H.S. Srinivasa, (2007) 10 SCC 572 (Harassment related to dowry demands falls under cruelty)"]}, {"argument": "The appellants, being part of the husband's family, were involved in the criminal breach of trust concerning the complainant's stridhan (dowry articles), constituting an offense under Section 406 IPC.", "precedents": ["Rashmi Kumar v. Mahesh Kumar Bhada, (1997) 2 SCC 397 (Stridhan entrustment to husband/relatives)", "Velji Raghavji Patel v. State of Maharashtra, AIR 1965 SC 1433 (Essentials of criminal breach of trust)", "Pratibha Rani v. Suraj Kumar, (1985) 2 SCC 370 (Stridhan property principles)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The criminal proceedings against the appellants are an abuse of the process of court, initiated with mala fide intention to harass distant relatives, warranting quashing under Section 482 CrPC.", "precedents": ["State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal, 1992 Supp (1) SCC 335 (Landmark case laying down grounds for quashing FIR/complaint)", "Neelu Chopra & Anr v. Bharti, (2009) 10 SCC 184 (Quashing justified for vague allegations against relatives)", "Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P., (2012) 10 SCC 741 (Tendency to rope in relatives, need for specific allegations)"]}, {"argument": "The complaint fails to disclose specific, prima facie evidence of the appellants' involvement in any offense under Sections 498A or 406 IPC.", "precedents": ["Kans Raj v. State of Punjab, (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Omnibus allegations insufficient)", "Sushil Kumar Sharma v. Union of India, (2005) 6 SCC 281 (Acknowledged misuse of Section 498A - 'legal terrorism')", "B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana, (2003) 4 SCC 675 (Acknowledges tendency for exaggeration in matrimonial disputes, permitted quashing on settlement)"]}]}
